Faults.message:
We're sorry about the power cut in the area. The power cut is affecting some properties in the area shown on the map, but not all. This is why you may notice some of your neighbours have power, but you don't. It is normal to see 1 in 3 homes affected. We are working with our engineers to fix the problem as quickly as possible, and well keep you updated here on PowerTrack.

Engineers have arrived in the area. They are working hard to fix the problem and will get your power back on as quickly as possible. At this stage, we're aiming to have your power back on by 16:00 05/10/2025. If this changes, we'll let you know.

The cause of this power cut is a fault on our overhead network. This is the most common type of fault we see, and our teams are very experienced in dealing with these issues. In most cases, our engineers are able to get your power back on by simply replacing a fuse at the local substation, however, if the fault is severe, this may take us longer to fix. If this does happen, we will let you know.

If you need more information, please send us a message on Whatsapp or call us on 105 and quote reference 'RU9834'

Faults.name: G83 Area

Faults.message:
We're sorry about the power cut in the area. The power cut is affecting 75 properties in the area shown on the map. We are working with our engineers to fix the problem as quickly as possible, and will keep you updated here on Power Track.

It's busier than usual just now, but we'll be sending our engineers to the area as soon as possible. When they're on their way, we'll let you know what time they'll be arriving. At this stage, we're aiming to have your power back on by20:00 06/10/2025.

We have had reports of an overhead power line coming down. When this happens, the power will automatically turn off to keep everyone safe. Our engineers know exactly where the problem is and are working hard to make the situation safe, repair the wire and get your power back on. These types of faults often require extensive work and specialist teams which is why the restoration time seems so far away. If we can restore power sooner, we promise we will do so.

If you need more information, please send us a message on Whatsapp or call us on 105 and quote reference 'RU8973'
Faults.name: PA25 & PA26 Areas

Faults.message:
This power cut has been caused due to the strong winds and adverse weather conditions Storm Amy is bringing across much of Scotland. The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind is so strong that in some places its not safe for our engineers to climb the poles to fix the problem. Because of this, its going to take us longer than normal to get the power back on. We know that this is a very long time but in previous storms, customers have told us they prefer to have this information at the start of a power cut so they can make alternative plans.
 
Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how theyll get the power back on as quickly as possible. Many engineers have already been moved to various locations across Scotland before the storm so theyre ready to respond the minute its safe to do so. If we can get your power back on sooner, we will.
 
Well continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If youre going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or theres something you need extra support with, please send us a message or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.
 
Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.
Faults.name: IV63 & PH19 Areas

Faults.message:
This power cut has been caused due to the strong winds and adverse weather conditions Storm Amy delivered across much of Scotland. The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

Faults.message:

We know that this is a very long time but in previous storms, customers have told us they prefer to have this information at the start of a power cut so they can make alternative plans.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away,they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible. Many engineers have already been moved to various locations across Scotland before the storm so they're ready to respond the minute it's safe to do so. If we can get your power back on sooner, we will.

The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

Faults.name: DD8 Area

Faults.message:
This power cut has been caused due to the strong winds and adverse weather conditions Storm Amy delivered across much of Scotland. The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

Faults.message:
This power cut has been caused due to the strong winds and adverse weather conditions Storm Amy delivered across much of Scotland. The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

Faults.name: IV18 Area

Faults.message:
This power cut has been caused due to the strong winds and adverse weather conditions Storm Amy is bringing across much of Scotland. The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind is so strong that in some places it's not safe for our engineers to climb the poles to fix the problem. Because of this, it's going to take us longer than normal to get the power back on. We know that this is a very long time but in previous storms, customers have told us they prefer to have this information at the start of a power cut so they can make alternative plans.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away,they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible. Many engineers have already been moved to various locations across Scotland before the storm so they're ready to respond the minute it's safe to do so. If we can get your power back on sooner, we will.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

Faults.message:
This power cut has been caused due to the strong winds and adverse weather conditions Storm Amy delivered across much of Scotland. The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

Faults.name: PA34 Area

Faults.message:
This power cut has been caused due to the strong winds and adverse weather conditions Storm Amy delivered across much of Scotland. The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

Faults.name: DD11 & DD5 Areas

Faults.message:
This power cut has been caused due to the strong winds and adverse weather conditions Storm Amy delivered across much of Scotland. The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.
Faults.name: AB43 Area

Faults.message:
This power cut has been caused due to the strong winds and adverse weather conditions Storm Amy delivered across much of Scotland. The strong winds have caused damage to our electricity network, most likely a tree or large branch hitting our wires. The wind was so strong that in some places, it was not safe for our engineers to climb poles.

The weather has improved slightly, and this means we have been able to start repairs in some areas and begin to get power restored in stages. There is however a large amount of damage across our network, and this is why you may see a longer restoration time than you were expecting. We appreciate this is a long time, however, want to provide customers with the chance to make alternative arrangements if they wish.

Our teams are working as hard as they can to get the power back on, and although our engineers may not be able to fix the problem right away, they are constantly reviewing the reports of damage to the network coming in and planning exactly how they'll get the power back on as quickly as possible.

We have begun to dispatch welfare units in areas where there are no road restrictions and where it's safe to do so. We are also offering reimbursement of costs for food and drink when your power is off for more than 12 hours. You can find out more on this at ssen.co.uk/stormsupport.

We'll continue to update the progress of this power cut here, and if you would like to be notified of any changes, you can do that by registering for updates at the bottom of this page.

If you're going to struggle at all without the power due to a medical condition or there's something you need extra support with, please send us a message on WhatsApp or call us on 105 and one of the team will be on hand to help 24 hours a day.

Thank you for your ongoing patience, understanding and support whilst our teams work around the clock to get the lights back on.
